column10: Everyone should have goals in mind when living. People who live without tangible goals must have a hard time continuing what they are doing. And even though the feeling you get when you imagine shooting past your goal, how you can see the target you had, while you fall to the ground. The feeling of failure, of despair, washing over you. How the earth seems to swallow you whole and the atmosphere changes in an instance. That feeling must be debilitating. But contrasting this with the feeling of accomplishment you get when you complete your goals, makes setting them worth it.

Once upon a time there was a man who wanted to marry the king’s daughter, so he went to the castle.
Once he arrived, there was a gate with three guards.

He comes to the 1st guard:
“Halt, who goes there?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Who?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Oooh, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Yeees, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“What brings you here?”
“I want to marry the king’s daughter.”
“OK, you may pass!”

He comes to the 2nd guard:
“Halt, who goes there?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Who?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Oooh, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Yeees, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“What brings you here?”
“I want to marry the king’s daughter.”
“OK, you may pass.”

He comes to the 3rd guard:
“Halt, who goes there?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Who?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Oooh, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Yeees, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“What brings you here?”
“I have come to marry the king’s daughter.”
“OK, go ahead.”

So the Red-blue knight on the white horse comes to the king:
“First of all, who are you?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Who?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Oooh, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Yeees, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“What do you want here?”
“I wish to marry your daughter!”
“OK, I agree — on the condition that you first defeat the three-headed dragon. For each head there are three guards. Good luck.”

Said and done. The Red-blue knight on the white horse sets off for the dragon. Once there, he comes to the 1st guard of the 1st head:

“Halt, who goes there?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Who?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Oooh, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Yeees, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“What brings you here?”
“I want to defeat the dragon!”
“Well then, I wish you the best of luck.”

He comes to the 2nd guard of the 1st head:
(same exchange)
“Well then, I wish you the best of luck.”

He comes to the 3rd guard of the 1st head:
(same exchange)
“Well then, I wish you the best of luck.”

Chop, chop, head off.

Then he comes to the 1st guard of the 2nd head:
(same exchange)
“Well then, I wish you the best of luck.”

He comes to the 2nd guard of the 2nd head:
(same exchange)
“Well then, I wish you the best of luck.”

He comes to the 3rd guard of the 2nd head:
(same exchange)
“Well then, I wish you the best of luck.”

Chop, chop, head off — one left to go! :P

He comes to the 1st guard of the 3rd head:
(same exchange)
“Well then, I wish you the best of luck.”

He comes to the 2nd guard of the 3rd head:
(same exchange)
“Well then, I wish you the best of luck.”

He comes to the 3rd guard of the 3rd head:
(same exchange)
“Well then, I wish you the best of luck.”

Chop, chop, head off — dragon dead.

Now he has to enter the castle again through the gate with the three guards:

“Halt, who goes there?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Who?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Oooh, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Yeees, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“What brings you here?”
“I want to speak to the king!”
“OK, go ahead.”

He comes to the 2nd guard:
(same exchange)
“OK, go ahead.”

He comes to the 3rd guard:
(same exchange)
“OK, go ahead.”

Then he comes to the king, who is rather forgetful:

“First of all, who were you again?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Who?”
“Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“Oooh, Red-blue knight on the white horse?”
“Yeees, Red-blue knight on the white horse!”
“What were you here for again?”
“To marry your daughter! And I have already defeated the dragon.”
“Oh. Then unfortunately I have bad news for you…”
“?”
“I don’t have a daughter…”

The old man had been a carpenter all his life. After practising woodworking since he was a mere teenager, he was finally able to retire. The past few years had been hard on him, as he had essentially been alone since his wife died. But the one thing she left him with, had been keeping him company in his workshop for the last few months. Every day when he started his machines, and he prepared his tools, he could reminisce on the life he had lived with her.

The war has been going on for ages but no one knows how it happened. There has been a standstill, a ceasefire for as long as we remember yet our defenses remain fortified. While nature has healed, our trauma has not.
Imagine being on top of the world, literally on top of a mountain. The view is stunning. Unfortunately, all I’m doing is looking for the enemy. Rumor has it they’re on their way to crush us.
Loneliness. Waiting. Staring at the horizon. No one around, but staying ever vigilant while keeping watch. The weight of the kingdom on your shoulders as the first line of defence.

column10: On a warm spring day, he looked out onto the world around him. He had been left alone here, keeping watch, for several months now. Despite this, every day he woke up to new rations to feed himself, and clean water to drink. Many animals came to visit his post, some hurriedly running from something, some curious, and some indifferent. Each would get an entry, each would get logged. What for, he did not know. How much longer, he could not tell. All he knew was to keep watch. On days like this though, that was no chore. The fresh air, the sweet breeze, and the pleasant sun, made him content to be keeping watch. Maybe even, happy.
